Acquisition of Land and Compensation Dispute
The Land Acquisition Officer awarded compensation, but the petitioner was dissatisfied and sought a reference to the civil court.
Assessment of Compensation as Business Income
The Income Tax Officer treated the compensation received by the petitioner as income from business, arguing that the land purchase was an adventure in the nature of trade.
Assessment of Compensation as Business Income
The Appellate Authority upheld the IT Officer's decision, indicating that the transaction was not a casual investment but rather a trade venture.
Arguments Regarding Nature of Transaction
The petitioner contended that the transaction was an isolated one and should not be classified as an adventure in the nature of trade.
Arguments Regarding Nature of Transaction
The department argued that purchasing land after the acquisition notification indicated a profit motive, thus classifying it as a trading venture.
Legal Principles on Adventure in Trade
The Tribunal examined the nature of the transaction in light of relevant legal provisions defining 'business' and 'adventure in the nature of trade.'
Legal Principles on Adventure in Trade
The Tribunal concluded that the petitioner had embarked on a venture with the intention of making a profit, thus suggesting the transaction was an adventure in the nature of trade.
Judicial Precedents on Isolated Transactions
Citing various precedents, the Tribunal noted that even a single transaction could be deemed an adventure in trade if profit-making elements are present.
Judicial Precedents on Isolated Transactions
The essence of whether a transaction constitutes an adventure in the nature of trade was underscored as a mixed question of law and fact.
Final Determination of Tax Liability
The court ultimately ruled that the transaction in question did not constitute an adventure in the nature of trade and thus the compensation received should not be taxed as business income.
Final Determination of Tax Liability
The decision emphasized that the purchase was made with the intention to receive compensation rather than to sell the land at a profit.
2818464: Theft of Motorcycle
The prosecution case is based on an online FIR regarding the theft of a motorcycle bearing registration number DL-5S-AK-3375 reported on 07.04.2016.
Theft of Motorcycle
The complainant alleged that his motorcycle was stolen from a specific location and subsequently lodged an e-FIR with the police.
Apprehension of Accused
On 14.04.2016, the accused was apprehended by the Special Staff of North East District while in possession of stolen vehicles, including parts of motorcycles.
Apprehension of Accused
The accused was arrested in connection with a number of theft cases and was alleged to have been dealing in stolen property habitually.
Recovery of Stolen Property
During the investigation, various parts of stolen vehicles, including several motorcycles and components, were recovered from the accused's premises as per his disclosure.
Recovery of Stolen Property
The police seized numerous stolen motorcycles, parts, and registration plates from the accused's house, which the accused confessed to having purchased from thieves.
Witness Testimonies
Multiple witnesses were examined, including the complainant and police officers who participated in the recovery operations.
Witness Testimonies
Testimonies corroborated the theft of the motorcycle and the accused's involvement in the possession and sale of stolen vehicles.
Legal Proceedings and Charges
The charge sheet was filed against the accused under relevant sections of the law pertaining to theft and possession of stolen property.
Legal Proceedings and Charges
The accused pleaded not guilty and claimed trial, leading to the examination of evidence and witnesses by the prosecution.
Defense Arguments
The defense argued that the complainant was not the rightful owner of the motorcycle, casting doubt on the prosecution's case.
Defense Arguments
The accused also contended that the recovery of stolen property was planted and that he had been falsely implicated.
Judicial Findings
The court found that the recovery of the motorcycle chassis and other stolen items at the instance of the accused was credible evidence.
Judicial Findings
The prosecution established that the accused was in possession of a significant quantity of stolen property, affirming the charges against him.
Double Jeopardy Considerations
The court addressed the issue of double jeopardy, noting that the accused could not be convicted again for the same offense but could be held liable for different offenses related to stolen property.
Double Jeopardy Considerations
The court clarified that even if the accused was previously convicted, he could still face charges for new violations of the law.
113907644: Issuance of Recovery Certificate
A certificate under the relevant section of the said Act was issued by Respondent No.2 in Recovery Application against certain respondents upon an application by the petitioners.
Issuance of Recovery Certificate
The recovery certificate, issued on a specific date, was for a substantial sum and contained a condition that its execution was subject to judgment in a related case.
Dispute in Co-operative Court
Pending the recovery proceedings, the respondents filed disputes in the Co-operative Court contesting the recovery, leading to the recovery certificate being issued with conditions.
Dispute in Co-operative Court
The Special Recovery Officer issued a demand notice to the borrowers and sureties for recovery of the due amount.
Challenging Demand Notice
One of the respondents challenged the demand notice in a case that resulted in a ruling quashing the notice on the grounds that disputes were pending before the Co-operative Court.
Challenging Demand Notice
It was noted that the recovery certificates had been issued but not challenged in the appropriate court, thus remaining valid.
Legal Relief Sought by Petitioners
The petitioners sought various reliefs, including the quashing of the Deputy Registrar's order which imposed a specific condition on the recovery certificate.
Legal Relief Sought by Petitioners
The petitioners also requested that the Co-operative Court expedite the resolution of the disputes filed against them.
Distinction of Jurisdictions
The court noted that the provisions of the relevant sections are distinct and operate in separate spheres, with an emphasis on the need for speedy remedies for societies against defaulting members.
Distinction of Jurisdictions
The court highlighted that making the recovery certificate's execution subject to pending disputes contradicted the intent of the legislative provisions.
Quashing of Conditional Clause
The court ultimately quashed the condition in the recovery certificate that made its execution contingent on the resolution of disputes in the Co-operative Court.
Quashing of Conditional Clause
It was determined that execution of the recovery certificate should not be subject to any pending matters in the Co-operative Court.
68770218: Motor Vehicle Accident

These four Appeals relate to a motor vehicle accident which took place on the night intervening 11-12.09.2005, resulting in the death of two occupants and injuries to three others travelling in a tempo.
Motor Vehicle Accident
The accident was attributed to the rash and negligent driving of the tempo's driver, leading to a tyre burst and loss of control over the vehicle.
Claim for Compensation
Five separate Claim Petitions were filed by the victims and legal representatives of the deceased, claiming various amounts of compensation for the losses incurred due to the accident.
Claim for Compensation
The Claims Tribunal awarded compensation based on the minimum wages applicable to unskilled workers, with adjustments for inflation and deductions for personal expenses.
Insurance Company’s Contestation

The Insurance Company contested the claims, asserting that the deceased were travelling as gratuitous passengers and that the driver lacked a valid driving license, thereby denying liability for compensation.
Insurance Company’s Contestation
The Insurance Company also argued that the compensation awarded was excessive and did not account for the lack of evidence on future income prospects.
Claims Tribunal's Findings
The Claims Tribunal determined that the deceased were travelling as owners or representatives of the goods, establishing the Insurance Company's liability to compensate the claimants.
Claims Tribunal's Findings
The Tribunal also recognized the Insurance Company’s right to recover compensation paid from the driver or owner due to breaches of policy conditions.
Statutory Liability of Insurance Companies

The legal principle established that the insurer has a statutory obligation to compensate third parties, even if there is a breach of the insurance policy, and can subsequently seek recovery from the insured.
Statutory Liability of Insurance Companies
Judicial precedents affirm that the insurer's liability to pay to third parties remains intact despite any violations by the insured, emphasizing the protective intent of statutory provisions.
Assessment of Compensation
The assessment of compensation considered the earnings of the deceased, with adjustments for future income prospects deemed inappropriate for self-employed individuals.
Assessment of Compensation
The Tribunal awarded amounts for loss of dependency, funeral expenses, and non-pecuniary damages, reflecting the totality of loss experienced by the claimants.
131003910: Apprehension of Accused
The police received information regarding the smuggling activities of heroin by the accused and apprehended them near a public place.
Apprehension of Accused
Both accused attempted to escape upon seeing the police but were apprehended.
Consent for Search
The Investigating Officer informed the accused of their rights and sought their consent for a search in the presence of a Gazetted Officer.
Consent for Search
The accused signed consent memos indicating their agreement to be searched.
Recovery of Drugs
During the search, heroin was recovered from the bags held by both accused, with separate samples being drawn and sealed.
Recovery of Drugs
The recovery was conducted in the presence of a Gazetted Officer as per the consent given by the accused.
Registration of FIR
A ruqa was prepared and sent to the Police Station leading to the registration of an FIR based on the recovery of heroin.
Trial and Conviction
The accused were put to trial after the completion of investigations and recording of witness statements.
Trial and Conviction
The prosecution presented evidence to establish the charges against the accused, which they denied.
Arguments Regarding Legal Provisions
The appellants argued that the Investigating Officer failed to reduce the secret information into writing, claiming it warranted their acquittal.
Arguments Regarding Legal Provisions
The State countered this argument by stating that the recovery occurred in a public place, negating the requirement for written information.
Presence of Gazetted Officer During Search
The appellants argued that the search should have been conducted in the presence of a Magistrate or Gazetted Officer, but it was established that a Gazetted Officer was present.
Independent Witnesses
The defense argued the absence of independent witnesses was detrimental to the prosecution, which was countered by the assertion that quality of evidence, not quantity, is what matters.
Previous Convictions of Accused
Evidence was presented regarding the prior convictions of one of the appellants under similar offenses, which was noted during the trial.
Final Verdict
The court dismissed both appeals, finding no illegality in the trial court's findings and upholding the conviction of the accused.
91134679: Allegations of Perjury
The High Court found that a prima facie case for perjury was established based on statements made in anticipatory bail applications.
Allegations of Perjury
The Sessions Court noted that statements made by the Applicants were allegedly knowingly false to obtain favorable orders.
Matrimonial Dispute
The case arose out of matrimonial proceedings involving allegations of infidelity by one party.
Matrimonial Dispute
The Applicants alleged that the Respondent was maintaining illicit relations, which led to the breakdown of the marriage.
Anticipatory Bail Applications
The Applicants filed anticipatory bail applications in both the Sessions Court and High Court, asserting that the allegations against them were false.
Anticipatory Bail Applications
The Sessions Court found that proceedings against the accused were premature as evidence had yet to be recorded.
High Court's Preliminary Findings
The High Court referred to a preliminary investigation report indicating that the allegations made in the bail application were false.
High Court's Preliminary Findings
The High Court concluded that there was a need for an enquiry based on the prima facie evidence of false statements.
Legal Principles on Perjury
The judgment discusses the necessity of establishing a deliberate falsehood before proceeding with perjury charges.
Legal Principles on Perjury
It emphasizes that mere inaccuracies in statements do not automatically warrant prosecution for perjury.
Judicial Caution in Perjury Prosecutions
The Court highlighted that initiating perjury proceedings requires careful consideration and should not be based on inconclusive evidence.
Judicial Caution in Perjury Prosecutions
There must be a clear foundation for the charge, beyond mere suspicion or frustration of litigants.
Evidence Standards for Perjury
The Court indicated that statements must be compared to unimpeachable evidence to ascertain their truthfulness.
Evidence Standards for Perjury
The preliminary investigation report was deemed insufficient as unimpeachable evidence against the statements made in court.
Implications of False Evidence
The Court noted the potential abuse of the judicial process if perjury complaints were filed based solely on contradictory statements.
Implications of False Evidence
It warned against the floodgates of litigation that could arise from frivolous perjury claims.
919364: Formation and Dissolution of Partnership
The petitioners were carrying on business in partnership which came into existence on a specific date.
Formation and Dissolution of Partnership
A partnership deed was executed, detailing the capital of the firm and the admission of a minor to the benefits of the partnership.
Formation and Dissolution of Partnership
The partnership was subsequently dissolved as per a deed of dissolution.
Non-registration of Deeds
The partnership deed and the deed of dissolution have not been registered under the applicable Act.
Non-registration of Deeds
It is noted that registration may not be obligatory, but the lack of registration is relevant to the case.
Land Holdings and Ceiling Limits
The firm held multiple plots of land exceeding the ceiling limit prescribed under the Act.
Land Holdings and Ceiling Limits
The land holdings were calculated and determined to exceed the allowed ceiling for urban areas.
Government Notice of Revision
The Government issued a notice indicating its decision to take up the matter for revision due to excess land holdings.
Government Notice of Revision
The firm was informed that no construction could be made on the land pending the decision.
Challenge to Government's Jurisdiction
The petitioners challenged the legality and validity of the Government's notice, arguing that the Government lacked jurisdiction to revise the matter.
Challenge to Government's Jurisdiction
It was contended that the Government's powers to issue interim orders were also not established.
Delay in Exercising Jurisdiction
The petitioners argued that the Government's revision was invalid due to an inordinate delay of over two years from the date of the original order.
Interpretation of the Act
The court examined the interpretation of the provisions of the Act, focusing on the nature of revisional powers of the Government.
Interpretation of the Act
It was clarified that the Government can review orders regardless of whether they are appealable.
Scope of Revisional Powers
The Government's revisional powers are discussed, including the circumstances under which they can be exercised.
Scope of Revisional Powers
The court emphasized that the Government can act on its own motion to ensure legality and propriety of orders.
Interim Orders under the Act
The court addressed the argument regarding the Government's power to issue interim orders while exercising its revisional jurisdiction.
Interim Orders under the Act
It was concluded that such power is implied as necessary to enforce the objectives of the Act.
Nature of Partnership Property
The distinction between co-ownership and partnership was clarified, emphasizing that property held by a partnership does not equate to co-ownership.
Nature of Partnership Property
The firm is treated as a unit for the purposes of land holdings under the Act.
Final Ruling on the Petition
The petition was ultimately dismissed, with the court rejecting the arguments presented by the petitioners regarding jurisdiction and interpretations of the Act.
74665339: The respondents filed a Civil Suit claiming entitlement to 1/7th share in a plot of land and the building standing thereon, asserting that they jointly shared and enjoyed the property as members of a Joint Hindu family under Mitakshara Hindu law.
The respondents discovered that the petitioners had sold the suit property by a sale deed, which prompted them to file a suit for declaration of their title and cancellation of the sale deed.
Contentions of the Petitioners Regarding Title
The petitioners contended that the suit land was purchased by them during their marriage, and the petitioner No.1 was the only signatory of the sale deed, thus asserting her absolute ownership.
The petitioners argued that the suit was barred by limitation as the name of petitioner No.1 had been mutated in the record of rights since 1976, and the suit was filed much later.
The petitioners, being Christians, argued they were not bound by Hindu Mitakshara law, claiming that the respondents could not assert rights under that law.

The respondents objected to the petitioners' claims, stating that there was no documentation proving the transfer of the suit land to the petitioners and asserting that the land and building belonged to all legal heirs of late [ENTITY].
The respondents maintained that sufficient cause of action was disclosed in their plaint, and that the suit should proceed to trial rather than being dismissed at the threshold.
The court determined that the claims of both parties warranted a trial to ascertain rights over the suit property, emphasizing the need for evidence to resolve disputes involving both fact and law.
17233281: Dishonoured Cheque
The complainant presented a cheque for Rs.6,60,000 issued by the accused, which was returned dishonoured with the remarks 'Exceeds Arrangements'.
Loan Agreement
The accused raised a loan of Rs.8,01,980 from the complainant, with assurances for repayment at the time of the loan agreement.
Demand Notice
The complainant issued a Demand Notice to the accused after the cheque was dishonoured, but the accused failed to make the payment within the stipulated time.
Plea of Not Guilty
The accused pleaded not guilty and claimed that they were falsely implicated in the case.
Burden of Proof
The court noted the burden of proof lies on the accused to rebut the statutory presumptions regarding the cheque issued.
Presumptions Under the Act
The judgment discussed statutory presumptions under the relevant sections of the Act regarding consideration for a negotiable instrument.
Involvement of Directors
The court highlighted the necessity for clear allegations against the directors regarding their responsibility in the business conduct of the company.
Contradictory Evidence
The complainant's testimony contained contradictions regarding the timing of promises for repayment and the issuance date of the cheque.
Failure to Prove Liability
The court determined that the complainant failed to prove the liability of the accused beyond reasonable doubt due to lack of corroborative evidence.
Acquittal of Accused
The court acquitted both accused due to the failure of the complainant to establish the guilt beyond reasonable doubt.
7798707: The allegations against the accused include being found in possession of a button actuated knife in contravention of provisions of the relevant Act.
The prosecution did not join public witnesses during the investigation despite their availability, which is deemed a critical flaw in the prosecution's case.
The testimony of official witnesses lacked corroboration from independent sources, raising doubts about the reliability of the evidence presented.
There were inconsistencies regarding the timeline of the seizure and registration of the FIR, suggesting that the seizure memo was prepared after the FIR was registered.
Benefit of doubt to the accused
The prosecution failed to prove its case beyond a reasonable doubt, leading to the conclusion that the accused is entitled to the benefit of doubt.
Legal obligation to involve independent witnesses
It is obligatory for the investigating officer to join independent witnesses during a search to lend authenticity to the investigation.
The court noted that the absence of public witnesses in a situation where many were present raises significant concerns regarding the conduct of the investigation.
76135044: Possession of Illicit Liquor
The accused was found in possession of a white plastic cane containing illicit liquor equivalent to 10 bottles of 750 ML each without any permit or license.
Possession of Illicit Liquor
The police, acting on secret information, constituted a raiding party and apprehended the accused while he was carrying the cane.
Seizure Procedure
The illicit liquor was seized, samples were drawn, and the remaining liquor was sealed with the seal of 'JK'.
Seizure Procedure
Documentation for the seizure was completed at the scene, leading to the registration of FIR No. 123/02.
Witness Testimony
The recovery witness supported the prosecution's case, detailing the events leading to the recovery of the illicit liquor.
Witness Testimony
The police witnesses testified about their roles in the seizure and the chain of custody for the evidence.
Lack of Independent Witnesses
The defense argued that the absence of independent witnesses during the search and seizure raises doubts about the authenticity of the police testimony.
Lack of Independent Witnesses
The court acknowledged that while the absence of independent witnesses is concerning, it does not automatically invalidate police testimony if credible.
Legal Standards for Search and Seizure
The court referenced legal precedents regarding the validity of searches conducted without independent witnesses and established that such irregularities do not necessarily vitiate the trial.
Legal Standards for Search and Seizure
It was noted that police testimony could still be credible even without independent corroboration, provided the evidence is coherent and reliable.
227510: Challenge to Labour Court award
The petitioner challenged the award of the Labour Court which rejected his demand for reinstatement with backwages.
Dismissal and Charges
The petitioner was dismissed after being chargesheeted for three charges following a regular departmental enquiry.
Dismissal and Charges
The Labour Court upheld the enquiry and the findings regarding the sufficiency of evidence for the two remaining charges.
Proven Charges
The charges that were upheld involved wilful insubordination or disobedience to lawful orders and causing damage to work or property.
Proven Charges
Evidence from the incident on 5.12.1980 supported the claim of wilful insubordination when the petitioner refused to drive a vehicle for an officer.
Incident on 5.12.1980
On 5.12.1980, the petitioner refused to drive a vehicle when ordered and laid down in front of it, preventing official duties from being performed.
Incident on 6.12.1980
The Labour Court found insufficient evidence to prove the alleged incident on 6.12.1980.
Misconduct Claims
The petitioner argued that he committed no misconduct and that even if misconduct was proven, the punishment was excessively harsh.
Legal Precedents Cited
The petitioner referenced various legal precedents to support claims that the punishment was disproportionate and that the Labour Court should have intervened.
High Court's Jurisdiction
The judgment discussed the limits of the High Court's jurisdiction in reviewing findings from departmental proceedings.
Insufficient Grounds for Intervention
The Labour Court found that the misconduct was proven and that the dismissal was justified based on the evidence presented.
Final Decision
The petition was dismissed as the Labour Court's award was not deemed perverse or illegal and the punishment was not disproportionately harsh.
963927: Assessment of Remuneration and Commission
The court considered whether the remuneration received by the assessees from the company was assessable under the relevant section of the Income Tax Act.
Assessment of Remuneration and Commission

The assessees contended that their income should be classified as business income instead of salary, asserting that they were joint managing directors acting in a capacity different from mere employees.
Reassessment Proceedings Validity

The court examined the legality of reassessment proceedings initiated under the Act, questioning if there was any omission or failure on the part of the assessees to disclose material facts necessary for assessment.
Reassessment Proceedings Validity
It was argued that all primary facts were known to the Income-tax Officer, thus challenging the grounds for reassessment.
Nature of Income - Business vs. Salary
The court analyzed whether the income derived from the company constituted salary or business income, emphasizing the distinctions between the roles of managing agents and employees.
Nature of Income - Business vs. Salary

The articles of association were scrutinized to ascertain the nature of the assessees' relationship with the company, considering if they acted under direct control or maintained independence in their management role.
Disclosure of Material Facts

The court deliberated on the requirement for assessees to disclose all material facts for assessment, determining that the Income-tax Officer had sufficient knowledge of the relevant facts and circumstances.
Disclosure of Material Facts
The contention was made that the mere absence of commission income in the returns did not imply a failure to disclose material facts, as these were already known to the assessing authority.
Legal Status of Joint Managing Directors

The court evaluated the legal status of the assessees as joint managing directors, determining their role as managing agents rather than mere employees, which impacted the tax treatment of their income.
Legal Status of Joint Managing Directors
The distinction between agents and servants was a focal point, with references to legal precedents and the implications of their decision-making authority in the company's management.
94171194: Challenge to Disciplinary Action
The petitioner challenges the order passed by the Central Administrative Tribunal which upheld the penalty of compulsory retirement imposed by the Disciplinary Authority.
Challenge to Disciplinary Action
The petitioner was chargesheeted while on deputation for disciplinary action under relevant sections of the applicable act.
Challenge to Disciplinary Action
The Inquiry Officer's report indicated that the charges against the petitioner were proved.
Delay and Laches
A preliminary objection was raised regarding the delay in filing the writ petition, with no reasonable explanation provided for this delay.
Delay and Laches
The Tribunal was criticized for allegedly failing to address the non-compliance of specific sections of the applicable act concerning the petitioner's case.
Delay and Laches
The High Court emphasized that the law of limitation is based on public policy and is applicable even in writ jurisdiction.
Principles of Natural Justice
The Tribunal found that all principles of natural justice were adhered to during the inquiry process.
Principles of Natural Justice
The petitioner was found to have committed serious misconduct including forgery and defamation of other authorities.
Judicial Precedents on Delay
The judgment referenced various precedents concerning the application of delay and laches, stating that the courts must weigh the scale of justice between both parties.
Judicial Precedents on Delay
It was noted that lack of a satisfactory explanation for delay can lead to dismissal of the case, even if the petitioner presents personal hardships.
Seriousness of Charges
The charges against the petitioner included forgery, attempting to bribe, and damaging the reputation of the authorities.
Seriousness of Charges
The Tribunal's findings regarding the gravity of the charges were upheld, reinforcing the penalty of compulsory retirement.
71732168: Writ Petitions filed under Article 226 for issuance of a Writ of Certiorarified Mandamus to call for the records relating to the impugned proceedings and quash the same.
Seeking to direct the respondents to revise and refix pay and other benefits from 2007, and to not recover the excess amount as ordered in the impugned letter.
The petitioner confined the argument to the recovery of amounts due to wrong fixation of pay scale, asserting it is covered by Supreme Court judgments disallowing recovery.
The legal principle that courts may relieve employees from hardship caused by recovery orders based on equity and judicial discretion was highlighted.
Courts have granted relief against recovery not based on employee rights, but to avoid undue hardship, especially for lower-rung employees who depend on their entire earnings for family upkeep.
Recovery of excess payments made for a long duration is considered iniquitous and arbitrary, particularly when such payments are made without employee knowledge or fault.
If excessive payments are detected after five years, recovery is deemed iniquitous and arbitrary, violating relevant sections of the law.
Recovery should not be pursued if it occurs after an employee's retirement or within one year of retirement.

The court referred to a previous case where a similar order of recovery was set aside due to the long duration of erroneous payments, reinforcing the principle against recovery after extended periods.
24745928: Road Traffic Accident
The petitioners suffered injuries in a road traffic accident involving a RTV bus driven in a high-speed and reckless manner by the driver.
Road Traffic Accident
The accident occurred when the RTV bus dashed against a car after overtaking another vehicle, resulting in the bus overturning and hitting a motorcyclist.
FIR Registration
An FIR was registered against the driver of the RTV bus, indicating the rash and negligent driving that led to the accident.
FIR Registration
The FIR included charges under relevant sections of law pertaining to road traffic incidents.
Negligence of Driver
The petitioners claimed that they sustained injuries due to the negligent driving of the respondent driver, which was corroborated by the police investigation and charge sheet.
Negligence of Driver
The Tribunal noted that the standard of proof required for establishing negligence in such cases is based on the preponderance of probabilities.
Liability of Respondents
The driver, registered owner, actual owner, and insurer of the offending vehicle were held jointly and severally liable for compensation to the petitioners.
Liability of Respondents
The insurer contested liability based on the absence of a valid driving license and vehicle permit at the time of the accident.
Compensation Determination
The Tribunal outlined the criteria for determining compensation, including both pecuniary and non-pecuniary damages.
Compensation Determination
The award of compensation was based on the nature of injuries, duration of treatment, loss of earnings, and other relevant factors.
Awarding Compensation
The Tribunal awarded varying amounts of compensation to each petitioner based on the severity of injuries and associated damages.
Awarding Compensation
Specific amounts were allocated for pain and suffering, medical expenses, loss of earnings, and attendant charges.
Insurance Company Obligations
The Tribunal directed the insurance company to pay the awarded compensation to the petitioners, with the right to recover amounts from the driver and owners.
Insurance Company Obligations
Interest on the compensation amount was mandated from the date of the petition until realization.
443172: Termination of Services
The respondent's services were terminated by an order stating that he would be paid one month's pay in lieu of notice.
Termination of Services
Respondent challenged the termination order, which was initially rejected by the Tribunal on grounds of delay.
Judicial Review of Termination
The High Court remitted the matter for decision on merits, finding that the termination was made without conducting an enquiry, thus violating a specific section of the applicable act.
Judicial Review of Termination
The High Court concluded that the termination was illegal as the enquiry into the respondent's alleged misconduct had not been completed.
Misapplication of Precedent
The High Court misinterpreted a precedent case, which involved a judicial officer, and failed to recognize the distinction between the cases.
Misapplication of Precedent
The correct legal principle was that an enquiry initiated against a delinquent must be pursued to its conclusion, which the High Court overlooked.
Power to Terminate Temporary Government Servants
The court acknowledged the government's power to terminate a temporary government servant without conducting an enquiry, as established in prior decisions.
Power to Terminate Temporary Government Servants
The court emphasized that termination simpliciter does not constitute a penalty and does not require an enquiry under the rules governing temporary government servants.
Entitlement to Salary and Benefits
The court ruled that the respondent must be deemed to have been in service from the date of termination until his superannuation, despite the termination being upheld.
Entitlement to Salary and Benefits
The respondent was not entitled to back wages from the date of termination until the filing of his petition but was entitled to arrears of salary and other benefits from a specified date.
164909679: Murder of the Deceased
The deceased was present outside his shop when he was called by the accused and taken to an adjoining street where he was shot.
Murder of the Deceased
After the shooting, the deceased was taken to the hospital where he was declared dead.
Previous Altercation and Grudge
Prior to the murder, there was an altercation between the accused and the deceased's brother, leading to a previous incident where the accused fired shots in the air.
Previous Altercation and Grudge
The prosecution argued that the murder was motivated by a grudge stemming from this earlier conflict.
Investigation and Evidence Collection
The police recorded statements from witnesses and gathered evidence including blood-stained earth and empty cartridges at the scene.
Investigation and Evidence Collection
A disclosure statement from one of the accused led to the recovery of a pistol, although no license was found.
Trial Court Acquittal
The trial court acquitted the accused due to lack of substantial evidence linking them to the crime, citing the absence of reliable eyewitness accounts.
Trial Court Acquittal
The trial court concluded that it was a blind murder with no observable witnesses to the occurrence.
Arguments on Appeal
The prosecution argued that the trial court failed to account for delays in witness statements and the natural presence of witnesses at the crime scene.
Arguments on Appeal
Defense counsel contended that the prosecution did not satisfactorily establish the presence of eyewitnesses and highlighted a significant delay in reporting the incident.
Legal Standard for Interference with Acquittal
The appellate court stated that acquittals should only be overturned when compelling reasons exist or if the trial court's reasoning was unreasonable.
Legal Standard for Interference with Acquittal
It was emphasized that if two plausible views exist regarding the evidence, the appellate court should defer to the trial court's judgment.
960471: Inconsistency in Court Decisions
Finding inconsistencies between two decisions of three-Judge Benches of this Court and the decision of a nine-Judge Bench, a two-Judge Bench referred a question of law to a larger Bench.
Claim for Refund after Final Assessment
The core legal question involved whether a claim for refund after final assessment is governed by a specific section of the Act.
Show Cause Notice Issued
A show cause notice was served on the manufacturer to explain why the declared prices should not be rejected and why prices charged by the distributor should not be approved.
Excise Duty Payment Under Protest
The manufacturer paid excise duty under protest and subsequently appealed to the Appellate Collector after the show cause notice was confirmed by the Department.
Amendment of Related Person Definition
The definition of 'related person' was introduced in the Act through an amendment, impacting the assessment of excise duty.
Refund Claims Filed
Multiple refund claims were filed by the manufacturer for the recovery of excess excise duty paid during specified periods.
Unjust Enrichment Debate
The learned Judge referred the question of unjust enrichment to the Full Bench due to its debatable nature.
Burden of Duty Passed On
The issue arose regarding whether the burden of duty was passed on by the manufacturer to the distributor and subsequently to the dealers.
Final Assessment and Refund Approval
The Department approved the ex-factory price of the manufacturer instead of the price list of the distributor, leading to the claimant starting to pay duty based on the ex-factory price.
Independent Application for Refund
The respondent claimed refund by filing an independent application, asserting that the conditions of the relevant section of the Act were not applicable.
Concurrent Findings of Authorities
The concurrent findings regarding whether the burden of duty had been passed on were challenged by the Department, leading to the current civil appeal.
Limitation Period for Refund Claims
The application for refund dated 11.2.1997 was deemed time-barred under the provisions of the relevant section of the Act.
Differentiation between Payments
The distinction between payments made under protest and provisional assessments was highlighted, with implications for claims of refund.
49999233: Quashing of Anticipatory Bail
The petitioner sought to quash the order granting anticipatory bail to the respondents, claiming it was issued without proper legal justification.
Quashing of Anticipatory Bail
The petitioner argued that the anticipatory bail granted was for unlimited time, which is contrary to established legal principles.
Allegations of Conspiracy and Forgery
The petitioner alleged that the respondents conspired to transfer funds from his bank account to another account based on a forged authority letter.
Allegations of Conspiracy and Forgery
An FSL examination confirmed that the petitioner's signature on the authority letter was forged, leading to a criminal complaint.
Issues of Custodial Interrogation
The petitioner contended that custodial interrogation of the respondents was necessary to investigate the conspiracy fully.
Issues of Custodial Interrogation
The petitioner claimed that the absolute anticipatory bail hindered the investigation, preventing effective questioning of the accused.
Legal Standards for Granting Anticipatory Bail
The judgment discussed the standards for granting anticipatory bail, emphasizing that it should not be for an unlimited duration without justification.
Legal Standards for Granting Anticipatory Bail
The Supreme Court's guidelines indicated that anticipatory bail is typically granted for a limited time except in certain circumstances.
Lack of Application of Mind by the Sessions Court
The High Court found that the Sessions Court's order granting anticipatory bail was made without adequate reasoning, reflecting a lack of application of mind.
Lack of Application of Mind by the Sessions Court
The judgment criticized the Sessions Court for failing to articulate the reasons justifying the grant of anticipatory bail in light of serious allegations.
Cancellation of Bail
The High Court outlined the criteria for cancelling anticipatory bail, emphasizing that cogent and overwhelming circumstances are required for such cancellation.
Cancellation of Bail
The court indicated that while cancellation of bail is serious, it can occur if the original bail order was made without proper justification.
43510861: Complaint Filing
The appellant filed a complaint under a specific section of the Act, which led to the case being taken cognizance by the learned Sub-Divisional Judicial Magistrate.
Allegation of Cheque Dishonour

The complainant alleged that the accused took an amount of Rs. 45 Lakhs for business investment but failed to return it, leading to the issuance of a cheque that was subsequently dishonoured due to insufficient funds.
Legal Notice Issuance
After the dishonour of the cheque, the complainant issued a legal notice to the accused, which the accused received but failed to respond to within the statutory period.
Territorial Jurisdiction Issue
The learned Magistrate acquitted the accused on grounds of lack of territorial jurisdiction, stating that the entire transaction occurred outside the jurisdiction of the Dibrugarh Court.
Appellant's Argument on Jurisdiction
The appellant contended that jurisdiction was proper as the cheque was presented in Dibrugarh and the dishonour occurred there, thereby establishing a cause of action within the court's jurisdiction.
Misinterpretation of Jurisdiction Law
The appellant argued that the learned Magistrate misinterpreted the law regarding territorial jurisdiction, which should allow for trial in Dibrugarh due to multiple acts occurring there.
Evidence of Payment Burden
The trial court found that the complainant failed to prove he had the substantial amount of Rs. 45 Lakhs at the material time, thus not discharging the burden of proof for payment to the accused.
Final Judgment on Acquittal
The trial court acquitted the accused based on the findings of both lack of territorial jurisdiction and insufficiency of evidence proving the complainant's claim.
Appeal Against Acquittal
The appeal challenged the acquittal on grounds of procedural errors regarding the consideration of jurisdiction and the merits of the case simultaneously.
Supreme Court Precedent on Jurisdiction

Citations from the Supreme Court were presented regarding the nature of jurisdiction in cheque dishonour cases, emphasizing that several acts contributing to the offence can occur in different localities.
Appellate Court's Power Analysis
The appellate court evaluated its powers to intervene in acquittals and emphasized that such intervention occurs only in exceptional cases with compelling circumstances.
187416474: The appellants were convicted for offences punishable under various sections of the Act, resulting in sentences of two to four years of rigorous imprisonment and fines.
The appellants were accused of entering into a criminal conspiracy to get building plans regularised in violation of lease terms and building bye-laws, causing wrongful loss to NDMC.

The charges against the appellants were contested on the basis that the main accused had died and that the trial court acquitted the Chief Architect and alleged beneficiary, undermining conspiracy claims against the appellants.
The acts for which the appellants were charged were official acts, and there were no allegations of illegal gratification, raising questions about the validity of misconduct charges.
It was established that compounding fees were collected on the entire covered area of the building, demonstrating that the interests of NDMC were safeguarded and no loss was incurred.
The regularisation file was reviewed and approved by the Chief Architect with conditions, indicating adherence to building bye-laws and proper administrative procedures.
The court considered the application for suspension of sentence pending appeal, highlighting factors such as the appellants' age, unblemished record, and lack of flight risk.
The appellants referenced several precedents to support their case for the suspension of sentence and to argue against the conviction based on misinterpretations of the law.
1968626: Validity of Tenancy Termination
The landlords served a notice to the tenant terminating the tenancy on grounds of bona fide requirement for non-agricultural use, leading to a legal challenge regarding the validity of the notice.
Validity of Tenancy Termination
The tenant contended that the notice of termination was not legal and claimed that the landlords did not bona fide require the land for the stated non-agricultural purpose.
Application for Possession
Following the termination of tenancy, the landlords filed an application for possession before the Tehsildar, which was granted despite the tenant's appeal.
Application for Possession
The appeals and revision applications filed by the tenant against the orders allowing possession were subsequently dismissed.
Amendment of Relevant Sections
The introduction of an amending act deleted certain provisions of the original act, leading to questions about the rights of landlords and tenants concerning possession of land.
Amendment of Relevant Sections
The amendment provided for the abatement of pending proceedings if the landlord had not taken possession as required under the new provisions.
Discrimination Based on Municipal Status
The amendment created distinction between landlords in municipal areas and those in non-municipal areas regarding the right to terminate tenancy for non-agricultural purposes.
Discrimination Based on Municipal Status
Arguments were made that the amendment discriminated against landlords in municipal areas by taking away their rights to evict tenants for bona fide non-agricultural use.
Constitutional Validity of the Amendment
Challenges were raised against the constitutional validity of the amendment, arguing it violated landlords' fundamental rights and was discriminatory.
Constitutional Validity of the Amendment
The court examined whether the restrictions imposed by the amendment satisfied the test of reasonableness and public interest as required by constitutional provisions.
Burden of Proof on the State
The absence of a state return was noted in the context of justifying the legislation as reasonable and in the public interest.
Burden of Proof on the State
The court emphasized that the burden of proof regarding the reasonableness of the amendment lies with those supporting the legislation.
Pending Proceedings and Possession
The court determined that pending proceedings where the landlord had not taken possession would abate, regardless of previous orders in favor of landlords.
Pending Proceedings and Possession
The ruling highlighted that tenants would retain possession in cases where landlords had not executed the order for possession.
1174506: Marriage Without Family Consent
The deceased had fallen in love with the accused and they got married without the consent of their family members.
Death of the Deceased
On the night of March 8/9, the informant found his sister with severe burn injuries, which resulted in her death after being hospitalized.
Filing of FIR
Following the death of the deceased, the informant lodged a complaint alleging that his sister was set on fire by her husband.
Charge Framing
The Chief Judicial Magistrate took cognizance of the police report and committed the case to the Sessions Judge, where charges were framed against the accused.
Prosecution Evidence
The prosecution examined multiple witnesses, including family members of the deceased, to substantiate the charges against the accused.
Defence Claims
The accused denied all charges and did not present any evidence in his defence during the trial.
Acquittal
The Addl. Sessions Judge acquitted the accused, concluding that the prosecution failed to prove its case beyond reasonable doubt.
Argument on Evidence Appreciation
The State contended that the trial court failed to appreciate the evidence properly and that the prosecution had established a case for conviction.
Nature of Cruelty and Dowry
The court examined the definitions of 'cruelty' and 'dowry' as relevant to the case and determined the absence of evidence supporting either claim.
Legal Presumption in Domestic Cases
The court discussed the legal presumption of dowry death and the burden of proof required from the accused in such cases.
Accidental Fire vs. Intentional Act
Medical testimonies indicated that the nature of the burns could be consistent with accidental fire, questioning the intent behind the injuries.
Final Ruling
The appellate court upheld the acquittal, stating that the evidence presented did not establish guilt beyond reasonable doubt, leading to the dismissal of the appeal.
99198525: Marriage and Birth
Respondent No.2 was married to petitioner No.1 and from the wedlock one daughter was born.
Allegations of Harassment
The petitioners started mentally and physically harassing respondent No.2, which compelled her to file a complaint.
Filing of Complaint
Respondent No.2 filed a complaint against the petitioners after experiencing harassment.
Framing of Charges
The petitioners were summoned and charges were framed against them, leading to the case becoming a State case.
Settlement of Dispute
The matter has been amicably settled between the parties with the intervention of friends, elders, and respectables.
Filing for Divorce by Mutual Consent
A petition for divorce by mutual consent has already been filed, with statements of the parties recorded.
Trial Court's Examination of Compromise
The trial Court was directed to examine the genuineness and validity of the compromise deed.
Report on Compromise Validity
The trial Court submitted a report indicating that the compromise is genuine and without any pressure or coercion.
Quashing of Proceedings
The petition is allowed and the pending case is quashed on the basis of the compromise.
Reference to Precedents
Judgments from the Supreme Court and Full Bench of this Court were referenced to support the decision to quash the proceedings.
189137302: Conviction and Sentencing
Appellants were convicted under specific sections of the Act and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment and fines, while being acquitted of other charges due to benefit of doubt.
Seizure of Narcotics
An intelligence officer received secret information regarding a heroin deal, leading to the search of a vehicle where heroin was discovered.
Arrest and Identification
The NCB team, accompanied by police officials, arrested one accused at the scene after another fled, and identified themselves to the accused.
Search Procedures
The vehicle was searched in the presence of independent witnesses, leading to the discovery of packets containing heroin.
Confession and Statements
The accused provided a confession regarding the purchase and sale of heroin, which was recorded under the provisions of the Act.
Defenses Raised by Accused
The accused claimed they were falsely implicated, denied involvement with the contraband, and stated that recovery was not conducted properly.
Prosecution's Evidence Presentation
Prosecution examined various witnesses, including police officials and a chemical examiner, to substantiate the case against the accused.
Procedural Challenges
Issues were raised regarding the admissibility of evidence, including the lack of independent witnesses and proper documentation during the search.
Legal Precedents Cited
The defense and prosecution referenced various legal precedents to support their arguments regarding the admissibility of confessions and procedural compliance.
Judgment Outcome
The appeals were dismissed on the grounds that the evidence presented warranted the convictions and that procedural irregularities did not invalidate the prosecution's case.
